abstract.p: This study examines whether the magnitude of post‐earnings‐announcement drift is related to the risk faced by arbitrageurs, who may view the anomaly as a trading opportunity. Consistent with this hypothesis, the magnitude of the drift is strongly related to the arbitrage risk measure developed by Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002). The effect of arbitrage risk is statistically and economically significant in a range of specifications. The results support the view of post‐earnings‐announcement drift as an underreaction to earnings information.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Post‐earnings‐announcement drift is the tendency for a stock's price to drift in the direction of an earnings surprise in the months following an earnings announcement. The drift is also commonly referred to as the SUE (standardized unexpected earnings) effect and appears to be an enduring feature of stock returns.1Researchers have proposed three general explanations for the SUE effect. Some believe the apparent drift is due to methodological shortcomings of the studies that document it. Others believe the drift represents systematic misestimation of expected returns following earnings surprises. Still others think the drift is the result of investors who underreact to value‐relevant earnings information. The third explanation, however, raises the question of why unbiased investors, call them arbitrageurs, do not or cannot eliminate the underreaction and enforce market efficiency.

In this paper, I present new evidence for the underreaction explanation. I hypothesize that post‐earnings‐announcement drift is attributable to investors who underreact to earnings surprises and arbitrage does not eliminate the drift because the required trades are risky. Following Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002), I define arbitrage risk as the idiosyncratic part of a stock's volatility that arbitrageurs cannot avoid by holding offsetting positions in other stocks or indexes. In other words, arbitrage risk is the component of a stock's risk that cannot be hedged. I propose that arbitrage risk may deter arbitrage by investors such as hedge funds and reduce their willingness to take positions in stocks they believe to be mispriced. Clearly, idiosyncratic risk should not be important to diversified investors. Like Wurgler and Zhuravskaya and Shleifer and Vishny (1997), however, I consider the realistic scenario that many arbitrageurs are highly specialized and therefore hold a few, relatively large positions at any one time. If specialized arbitrageurs are important, then idiosyncratic risk may be relevant.

The results show that the magnitude of post‐earnings‐announcement drift is significantly positively correlated to arbitrage risk after controlling for a wide range of explanatory variables used in prior research. Firms in the highest arbitrage‐risk quintile experience drifts that are, ceteris paribus, between 3 to 4 percentage points per quarter larger than firms in the lowest arbitrage‐risk quintile. For example, in one test, extreme positive (negative) earnings‐surprise decile stocks in the highest arbitrage‐risk quintile exhibit 3‐month postannouncement abnormal returns of 5.21% (−5.46%), while those with in the lowest arbitrage‐risk quintile exhibit drifts of only 1.32% (−1.65%). Further, arbitrage risk, which is estimated ex ante as individual firm volatility, manifests itself as cross‐sectional uncertainty in future abnormal performance. This confirms the theoretical premise of the empirical approach, that investors who would profit from the greater apparent mispricing of high‐arbitrage‐risk firms must be prepared to bear greater uncertainty regarding the actual outcome of any individual transaction.

Of the three typical explanations for the SUE effect—methodological shortcomings, misestimation of expected returns, and investor underreaction—only investor underreaction predicts a positive relation between arbitrage risk and the drift. I therefore interpret the results just outlined as evidence that many investors underreact to earnings information, and risk impedes arbitrageurs from trying harder to profit from this underreaction.
Section IIreviews the relevant literature and motivates the central empirical test.Section IIIdiscusses the variables and the empirical framework.Section IVpresents the results andSection Vconcludes.

fn.p: Fama (1998) refers to the drift as the “granddaddy of all underreaction events” (p. 286). I use the terms post‐earnings‐announcement drift and the SUE effect interchangeably.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Potential Explanations for the Drift
sec.p: One implication of the semi‐strong form of the efficient market hypothesis is that prices should respond quickly and in an unbiased manner to new information such as earnings announcements. But for at least 3 decades researchers have been aware of an apparent delay in the stock‐price response to earnings information. One of the first papers to document post‐earnings‐announcement drift was Jones and Litzenberger (1970).2They hypothesize that earnings surprises should cause gradual, rather than immediate, price adjustments because the opinions of those best able to assess the surprises (market professionals) “would be gradually disseminated to the general investing public through advisory services, stock brokers etc.” (p. 144).3This obviously contrasts with the strict view of semi‐strong market efficiency.

Bernard and Thomas (1990) present the most‐often‐cited evidence in favor of the underreaction explanation. They show that, following an earnings surprise, returns around subsequent earnings announcements exhibit positive and declining first‐, second‐, and third‐order serial correlation and negative fourth‐order serial correlation. This is the same autocorrelation pattern that Foster (1977) documents for seasonally differenced earnings. Bernard and Thomas show that this autocorrelation pattern in returns is consistent with investors significantly underestimating (or being completely unaware of) the autocorrelation in seasonally differenced earnings. In other words, these results suggest that investors underweight the implications of current earnings for future earnings.

Not every researcher shares the view that the SUE effect represents an underreaction to earnings information and is, therefore, an arrant violation of market efficiency. Many point out methodological weaknesses in existing studies, and others believe that researchers systematically missestimate expected returns following earnings announcements.

There are a number of methodological pitfalls. The earliest drift papers, for example, use assumed rather than actual earnings announcement dates (e.g., Jones and Litzenberger1970and Latané et al.1970). Later papers, such as Joy, Litzenberger, and McEnally (1977), use actual dates. Another issue is that most studies classify stocks as buys or sells based on the standing of their earnings surprise relative to others of the same calendar quarter. Holthausen (1983) points out this imparts a look‐ahead bias by assuming that investors know, at the beginning of the quarter, what will be the distribution of surprises. Foster, Olsen, and Shevlin (1984) avoid this criticism by categorizing stocks based on where the earnings surprise would have placed the firm in the prior quarter's distribution of surprises.4

More recent research continues to raise methodological concerns. Jacob, Lys, and Sabino (2000) provide evidence that Bernard and Thomas's (1990) findings supporting underreaction may be due to the specific earnings model they use. Jacob et al. argue, “The persistence of the [drift] phenomenon is rather puzzling. If the cause were investors' naiveté, as BT propose, one would expect arbitragers to take advantage of this naiveté causing the phenomenon to disappear over time” (p. 332).

The third explanation for the drift is that researchers misestimate expected returns. For example, Foster et al. (1984) find no post‐earnings‐announcement drift when they assess the sign and magnitude of earnings surprise using stock‐price movements instead of the earnings‐based models used in other studies. They conclude, “The priced‐based expectations models have the appealing property that the assignment of firms to unexpected earnings change portfolios better approximates the independence‐over‐time assumption than do models used previously. This property means that abnormal returns reported for each earnings change portfolio are less likely to capture firm‐specific variables priced by the capital market but not incorporated into abnormal return estimation” (p. 598). One may interpret this to imply, as do Dyckman and Morse (1986), that the drift may be caused by an unobservable priced risk factor.

Finally, Ball, Kothari, and Watts (1993) argue that there should be a positive relationship between changes in a firm's investment risk and its expected earnings. That is, firms that experience positive (negative) earnings innovations tend to be those whose riskiness has recently increased (decreased). So, expected returns are systematically under‐ (over‐)estimated for positive (negative) surprise firms. To support their view, they provide evidence that, around earnings surprises, betas shift in the expected direction. The shift is, however, far too small to explain the magnitude of the actual drift.

fn.p: Ball and Brown (1968) were the first to document an apparent delay in the stock‐ price reaction to earnings. On the basis of small abnormal returns estimates, however, they conclude that prices respond to earnings “without bias, at least to within transactions costs” (p. 174). Jones and Litzenberger (1970) find a drift for positive surprises but not for negative surprises. A nearly contemporaneous study by Latané, Joy, and Jones (1970) finds drifts for both positive and negative surprises.

Hong and Stein (1999) formalize this idea. Daniel, Hirshleifer, and Subrahmanyam (1998) and Barberis, Shleifer, and Vishny (1998) offer behavioral explanations for why some investors might underreact to new information.
Bernard and Thomas (1990) report that the magnitude of the drift is insensitive to this research design choice.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Arbitrage Risk and Post‐Earnings‐Announcement Drift
sec.p: To many, the SUE effect seems simply too transparent, too easily exploitable to represent systematic market mispricing. Even if some investors tend to underestimate the value implications of earnings innovations, as Jacob et al. (2000) and others ask, why don't arbitrageurs exploit the drift to the point of eliminating it? In this paper, I explore the idea that real‐world arbitrage is risky. Two recent papers suggest this view of arbitrage.

Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002) point out that a specialized arbitrageur's demand for a stock is inversely related to the stock's arbitrage risk, which is essentially its idiosyncratic risk. In traditional portfolio theory, portfolio risk, and therefore a diversified investor's demand, is not affected by a security's idiosyncratic risk. But one could argue that traditional portfolio theory does not pertain to hedge funds, for example. Wurgler and Zhuravskaya suggest that many hedge funds do not hold diversified portfolios and state, “The dramatic experience of Long‐Term Capital Management in the fall of 1998 is sufficient to make this point; the fund's failure can ultimately be traced to a single unfortunate trade made on Russian debt.”

Shleifer and Vishny (1997) also suggest that idiosyncratic risk impedes arbitrage. In their model of delegated arbitrage, “All else equal, high volatility will deter arbitrage activity. To specialized arbitrageurs, both systematic and idiosyncratic volatility matters. In fact, idiosyncratic risk probably matters more because it cannot be hedged”(p. 51).5The models of Wurgler and Zhuravskaya and Shleifer and Vishny imply that stocks with higher idiosyncratic risk should be less attractive to arbitrageurs. On observing equivalent earnings surprises, arbitrageurs may, therefore, take smaller positions in stocks with higher idiosyncratic risk. If other investors underreact to earnings announcements, then high idiosyncratic‐risk stocks will be more mispriced and therefore exhibit greater drifts.6

While Wurgler and Zhuravskaya infer mispricing from the event‐day abnormal return to an S&P 500 index inclusion, I examine it directly by looking at subsequent abnormal returns. I examine the abnormal return following one earnings announcement up to and including the next one. The null hypothesis is that post‐earnings‐announcement drift is independent of a stock's arbitrage risk. The alternative is that the drift increases in arbitrage risk.

fn.p: Understandably, those who trade on earnings information are not very forthcoming and their exact methods tend to be proprietary. Direct evidence that investors who attempt to exploit the drift care about idiosyncratic risk is, therefore, sparse. However, one portfolio manager, who oversees a portfolio of about $1 billion and bases security selection primarily on earnings surprise, concentrates his holdings among 40 stocks. He stated that he filters out stocks with “unacceptably high stock price volatility” early in the stock‐selection process. Also, one partner of a hedge‐fund advisory service confided that the firm has several clients who hold fewer than 25 long (and short) positions. Idiosyncratic risk could certainly play a role in portfolios of this size.

In different contexts, Baker and Savasoglu (2002) and Pontiff (1996) relate idiosyncratic risk to the returns to arbitrage. Baker and Savasoglu show that the returns to risk arbitrage are increasing in a specific form of idiosyncratic risk, the uncertainty that a given merger will be completed. Pontiff demonstrates a greater disparity between the prices and net asset values of closed‐end funds whose underlying assets are more unique.

sec.title: Earnings surprise
sec.p: To address outliers and potential nonlinearities in the abnormal return‐SUE relation, Bernard and Thomas (1990) and others (e.g., Bhushan1994and Bartov, Radhakrishnan, and Krinsky2000) transform SUEs into coded/decile scores based on their rank within each calendar quarter. Bernard and Thomas scale the coded scores from 0.0 to 1.0. In a regression of abnormal returns on SUE scores, this allows interpretation of the slope coefficient as the difference in abnormal returns between the most positive and most negative SUE deciles. I adopt the Bernard and Thomas procedure with the modification used by Affleck‐Graves and Mendenhall (1992) of subtracting 0.5 from the coded scores. The intercept of a regression of abnormal return on SUE then represents the abnormal return for a hypothetical median observation between the two middle SUE deciles and should be close to zero.8

fn.p: Results are very similar and inferences are unaltered when omitting observations with zero variability in the forecasts.
It can easily be shown that, when using multiplicative explanatory variables such as those used here, failing to make an adjustment like this leads to biased coefficient estimates.

sec.title: Post‐earnings‐announcement abnormal returns
sec.p:
I measure post‐earnings‐announcement returns as the compound abnormal return from the day following the earnings announcement, as reported by Compustat, through the day of the first subsequent earnings announcement. The compound abnormal return is computed as the buy‐and‐hold return on the stock minus the buy‐and‐hold return on the CRSP (Center for Research in Security Prices) equally weighted size‐decile (based on market capitalization of equity) of which the stock is a member at the beginning of the calendar year. fn.p: The sample consists of both exchange‐traded (NYSE and Amex) stocks as well as Nasdaq stocks. Market capitalization deciles and expected returns are determined separately for each group. That is, exchange‐traded (Nasdaq) stocks are assigned to deciles based on the size distribution of NYSE‐Amex (Nasdaq) firms. In calculating abnormal returns, exchange‐traded (Nasdaq) sample firms' raw returns are compared to the returns of an equally‐weighted index of NYSE‐Amex (Nasdaq) firms of the same size decile.
I report the results of robustness tests regarding this and other research design choices later.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Explanatory Variables
sec.p: This paper uses six explanatory variables: arbitrage risk and hedgable risk; two variables intended to capture transactions costs; and two intended to proxy for investor sophistication. I discuss the motivation and the construction of these variables next.

sec.title: Arbitrage risk and hedgable risk
sec.p: Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002) use two different hedging assumptions to estimate the company‐specific risk an arbitrageur faces when owning or shorting a particular stock. The first assumption is that arbitrageurs hedge using only the S&P 500. The second assumption is that arbitrageurs hedge with three stocks that “match the subject stock on industry and as closely as possible on size and book‐to‐market.” Wurgler and Zhuravskaya estimate a firm's arbitrage risk, therefore, as the residual variance from a regression of its excess returns on those of substitutes. In the first case, the independent variable is simply the excess return of the S&P 500. In the second case, the independent variables are the excess returns of each of the three matched stocks.

Wurgler and Zhuravskaya's two estimates of arbitrage risk exhibit a cross‐sectional correlation of 0.98 and, not surprisingly, give very similar results. The high correlation between the two arbitrage risk estimates and the similar results they provide suggest that arbitrage risk can be usefully estimated by a simple statistic, the residual variance from a traditional market model regression. I therefore estimate a stock's arbitrage risk as the residual variance from a regression of its returns on those of the S&P 500 estimated over the 48 months ending 1 month prior to the earnings announcement. Shleifer and Vishny (1997) suggest that both systematic and idiosyncratic risk may be important to investors. I therefore estimate the systematic or hedgable risk as EXPRISK, defined as the explained variance from the regression used to estimate ARBRISK.

sec.title: Transactions costs proxies
sec.p: Garman and Ohlson (1981) show that, in the presence of trading frictions, security prices may rationally differ from “frictionless prices” by as much as round‐trip transactions costs. In the case of positive (negative) earnings surprises, this suggests that prices immediately following earnings announcements could be biased downward (upward) by an amount equal to transactions costs. The magnitude of the drift, therefore, could be positively related to the costs of trading the security.

Stoll (2000) shows that both recent stock price and recent dollar trading volume are significantly associated with one cost of trading, the bid‐ask spread. Bhushan (1994), based in part on discussions with institutional money managers, contends that stock price is negatively related to commissions. He also argues that recent dollar trading volume is negatively associated with trading costs, such as price pressure and the time required to fill an order. For these reasons, I follow Bhushan and include the explanatory variables PRICE, the CRSP closing stock price 20 days prior to the earnings announcement, and VOLUME, the CRSP daily closing price times the CRSP daily shares traded averaged over days −270 to −21 relative to the announcement.11

fn.p: Since the sample includes both exchange‐traded and NASDAQ stocks I make the common adjustment of dividing the volume of NASDAQ stocks by 2.0.

sec.title: Investor sophistication proxies
sec.p: Hand (1990) shows that the likelihood prices properly reflect a certain type of information depends on the probability that the marginal investor is “sophisticated” as opposed to being “naive.” The underreaction hypothesis of the drift may be interpreted as suggesting that some (naive) investors underestimate the implications of current earnings innovations for future earnings levels while other (sophisticated) investors do not. Applied to the SUE effect, Hand's model says that, when the marginal investor is likely to be sophisticated, the drift is small (Bartov et al.2000). Hand suggests the probability that the marginal investor is sophisticated may be approximated by the fraction of shares held by institutions. I take this data from CDA Spectrum and define INST as the fraction of shares held, in the calendar quarter prior to the earnings announcement quarter, by institutions required to file Security and Exchange Commission (SEC). Form 13f. Another variable that may be related to investor sophistication is the number of analysts who follow the stock (Bhushan1994). ANUM is the number of analysts reporting quarterly forecasts to I/B/E/S in the 90 days prior to the earnings announcement.

sec.title: Variable transformations
sec.p: To allow for time trends in variables, such as analyst following, and to account for possible nonlinearities, Bhushan (1994) and Bartov et al. (2000) use within‐year rank scores for some of their explanatory variables. For these reasons, I code each explanatory variable the same way I code SUE. The coded score is based on the observation's decile rank for that variable among all observations occurring within the same calendar quarter. The ranks are then transformed to range between −0.5 to +0.5. I give an example to illustrate how this coding scheme aids in interpreting the results.

Table 2contains few surprises. The average SUE is close to zero and the distribution exhibits a large standard deviation due to some observations with very small denominators. (Since the tests use coded scores, these outliers do not affect the results.) The mean abnormal return is close to zero. The distributions of VOLUME, PRICE, and INST are generally comparable to those reported in Bartov et al. (2000) but somewhat higher. This is not surprising since I use analysts' forecasts and require at least two current forecasts to compute a standard deviation. ANUM is somewhat lower than that reported by Bhushan, because he uses the number of analysts making annual forecasts, while I use the number producing the quarterly forecasts on which the earnings surprise is based.

Arbitrage risk and explained risk are similar to but somewhat higher than those reported in Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002).12Since their sample consists solely of firms entering the S&P 500, a generally large‐cap index, it is not surprising that their firms exhibit lower average risk than those studied here. The ratio of ARBRISK to EXPRISK for the two studies is however comparable. Wurgler and Zhuravskaya report a ratio of 6.7 and the corresponding number here is 7.1.

fn.p: Wurgler and Zhuravskaya estimate risk using daily returns, while I estimate it on a monthly basis. In comparing their results to mine, I adjust Wurgler and Zhuravskaya's risk estimates by multiplying them by 21 (the approximate number of trading days in a month).

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Regression Tests
sec.p: Following Bhushan (1994) and Bartov et al. (2000), I use interaction variables to test whether the SUE‐drift relationship is different for stocks with different characteristics. Since a regression slope coefficient is the expected change in the dependent variable for a 1 unit change in the independent variable, coding SUE deciles from −0.5 to +0.5 allows interpretation of the coefficient on SUE as the average difference in abnormal returns between observations in the highest‐ and lowest‐SUE deciles. To assess how ARBRISK and the other explanatory variables might affect the magnitude of the drift, I use interaction variables to allow the slope of the SUE‐return relation to vary with each firm characteristic. Coding explanatory variables from −0.5 to +0.5 allows the coefficient on each interaction variable to be interpreted as the additional spread in abnormal returns, between high‐ and low‐SUE stocks, for observations in the highest versus lowest decile of the firm characteristic.

These results are presented intable 3. The coefficient on SUE of 6.975 indicates that, for observations with median firm characteristics, the abnormal returns of those in the highest‐SUE decile exhibited 3‐month abnormal returns 6.975 percentage points higher than those in the most‐negative‐SUE decile. The main result intable 3is that the drift is strongly increasing in arbitrage risk. The coefficient on the SUE*ARBRISK interaction is 6.815, indicating that, after attempting to control for other potential explanatory variables, the spread between the abnormal returns of most‐positive‐ and most‐negative‐SUE deciles is nearly 7 percentage points larger for firms in the highest arbitrage‐risk decile than for firms in the lowest arbitrage‐risk decile.13

Both the standardt‐statistic (t= 6.81) and the Fama‐MacBetht‐statistic (t= 5.21) indicate that the coefficient is significantly different from zero.14The coefficient on SUE*ARBRISK is positive 29 of the 36 calendar quarters (80.6%). Thez‐statistic, which is calculated using the normal approximation to the binomial distribution and appears in the last column oftable 3, is 3.67, indicating that the fraction of quarters for which the coefficient is positive is reliably greater than one‐half. AnF‐test performed by estimating the regression with and without SUE*ARBRISK (omitting SUE*EXPRISK in each case) indicates that the model including arbitrage risk explains significantly more variation in the magnitude of the drift than when it is omitted (F= 53.20).

Consistent with Bhushan's (1994) results, the coefficient on SUE*VOLUME is also significant in the expected direction. The result suggests that the drift is larger for less liquid stocks, which also supports the underreaction interpretation of the drift, since a lack of liquidity can also be an impediment to arbitrage (Kyle1985). The significance of trading volume suggests that, consistent with Garman and Ohlson (1981) and Bhushan (1994), the lower are the costs of trading, the closer arbitrageurs drive a stock's price to its fundamental value.

Note that the coefficient on the explained or hedgeable risk interaction, SUE*EXPRISK, is insignificant. This result supports Wurgler and Zhuravskaya's (2002) proposition that only the idiosyncratic component of a stock's risk—the part that cannot be hedged—is important to specialized arbitrageurs. Pontiff (1996) documents a similar result.

The second regression test focuses on a subsample of observations whose earnings surprises place them into either the most‐extreme‐positive‐ or most‐extreme‐negative‐SUE decile. Bernard and Thomas (1989) show that the surprise‐drift relation is concave. Within these extreme SUE deciles I find that the correlation between earnings surprise (uncoded SUE) and QTRCAR is 0.00 for the highest‐SUE decile and 0.01 for the lowest‐SUE decile. These correlations imply that, within the most‐extreme‐SUE deciles, the earnings‐drift relationship is essentially flat. When using these subsamples to assess the effect of explanatory variables on the drift, therefore, there is no need to control for earnings surprise, which means the interactive specification is unnecessary. As a result, the coefficients are somewhat simpler to interpret. The explanatory variables for this regression are the coded decile scores (coded to range between −0.5 and +0.5) of the variables described intable 1, but unlike the tests oftable 3these variables are not multiplied times SUE.

To maximize the power of the test, I pool observations whose earnings surprises place them in either the highest‐ or lowest‐SUE decile. To accommodate this pooling, I specify QTRCAR as the dependent variable for good‐news announcements and QTRCAR times −1.0 as the dependent variable for bad‐news announcements.15Each coefficient can therefore be interpreted as the effect of the explanatory variable (in the expected direction based on SUE) on abnormal returns. For example, the coefficient on ARBRISK is the estimated difference between the positive (negative) abnormal returns for good‐news (bad‐news) observations that rank in the highest‐ARBRISK decile versus those in the lowest‐ARBRISK decile.

Results presented intable 4confirm those presented intable 3. The intercept of 3.535 is the expected positive (negative) abnormal return of extreme‐positive‐ (negative‐) SUE decile observations with median firm characteristics. Doubling this value to 7.07% gives an estimated spread between the abnormal returns of extreme‐positive‐ and extreme‐negative‐SUE observations. sec.label: B.
sec.title: Graphical Representation of the Effect
sec.p:
Figure 1graphically illustrates two important points. First, it shows the effect of arbitrage risk on the drift. Second, it confirms that arbitrage risk, which is estimated ex ante as individual firm volatility, manifests itself as cross‐sectional uncertainty in quarterly returns.Figure 1includes only observations whose earnings surprises place them in the two extreme‐SUE deciles, arguably those observations most likely to capture arbitrageurs' attention. I then divide these observations into arbitrage‐risk quintiles. This provides 10 subsamples: two news categorizations (extreme good and bad news) times five arbitrage‐risk quintiles.Figure 1is a plot of the average post‐earnings abnormal return (QTRCAR) of these 10 subsamples against the cross‐sectional standard deviation of QTRCAR within the subsample. Fig. 1.—
The mean and standard deviation of post‐earnings‐announcement drift, for positive and negative extreme SUE deciles, by arbitrage risk. QTRCAR is the stock's compound return from day +1 relative to the earnings announcement through the day of the subsequent announcement, minus the compound return of the corresponding CRSP equally‐weighted size decile. SUE is actual quarterly earnings per share minus the mean analyst forecast from I/B/E/S divided by the standard deviation of the forecasts. Arbitrage risk is the residual variance from a market model regression of the stock's monthly returns on those of the S&P 500 for the 48 months ending one month prior to the announcement.

For the lowest ARBRISK quintile the post‐announcement abnormal returns for the extreme‐positive‐ and ‐negative‐SUE deciles are 1.32% and −1.65%, respectively. For the highest ARBRISK quintile, corresponding numbers are 5.21% and −5.46%, respectively. In each case, the difference in the one‐way (good or bad news) magnitude of the drift between the lowest‐ and highest‐ARBRISK quintiles is about 3.8%. These numbers are roughly comparable to the 3.744% ARBRISK coefficient that appears intable 4and their sum (7.74%) is comparable to the 6.815% coefficient intable 3.

Figure 1shows that partitioning the sample according to arbitrage risk not only discriminates on average return (as the regressions indicate) but also segments the sample on the basis of ex post cross‐sectional risk. This validates the empirical approach of estimating arbitrage risk as the idiosyncratic volatility of an individual firm. Arbitrageurs who attempt to profit from the greater apparent mispricing of high‐arbitrage‐risk firms bear greater uncertainty regarding the outcome of any individual transaction.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Robustness
sec.p: Since this paper is a member of a literature that has been subject to an unusual number of methodological debates, it is important to examine whether the main result in this paper is robust to other specification choices. Here, I briefly discuss some of the alternative methods used.

sec.title: Dependent variable
sec.p: The results presented here are robust to cumulating returns instead of compounding them, replacing the firm's size‐decile return inequation (2)with the return on either the S&P 500 or the CRSP value‐weighted index and using a 63‐trading‐day event window for each observation instead of the period between announcements.16As stated previously, the results presented do not include observations whose abnormal returns fall into the extreme 1% tails. Inferences are robust to including all observations, trimming at the 0.5% level, or winsorizing abnormal returns at the 5th and 95th percentiles.

Results are also robust to using an alternative return window motivated by Bernard and Thomas (1990). Bernard and Thomas show that, following an earnings surprise, returns around subsequent earnings announcements exhibit a positive and declining first‐, second‐, and third‐order autocorrelation and negative fourth‐order autocorrelation. They and others use the sum of the abnormal returns for days −2 through 0 for the subsequent three earnings announcements minus the abnormal returns around the fourth following earnings announcement as an alternative specification for the drift. Results using this return interval are much weaker (for both SUE and ARBRISK) than those for QTRCAR, but ARBRISK remains significant at the 1% level.

fn.p: The mean and median number of trading days between announcements is 63. Marais (1989) recommends the method used in this paper because it avoids double counting any daily returns.

sec.title: Independent variables
sec.p: Redefining the SUE denominator with the standard deviation of past detrended, deseasonalized earnings (e.g., Bernard and Thomas1989,1990), no inferences are altered. Findings are also insensitive to the specific form of the independent variables. For example, inferences are not altered when replacing the coded‐decile scores of the explanatory variables with their natural logs. Also,table 3results are essentially unchanged when the regression includes levels terms as well as interactions with SUE. That is, the results are robust to allowing the intercepts, as well as slopes, to depend on each explanatory variable.

sec.title: Estimates of arbitrage risk
sec.p: When I substitute idiosyncratic risk as measured using daily returns (days −270 through −21) or weekly returns (weeks −56 through −5) for the monthly arbitrage risk measure used earlier, results are similar. Estimating arbitrage risk as the residual variance from a regression of the stock's excess return on the excess returns of the CRSP value‐weighted index, the Ibbotson corporate bond index, and the Ibbotson long‐term government bond index, as in Pontiff (1996), gives similar results.

sec.title: Trading system
sec.p: The samples used in many previous SUE studies are limited to exchange‐traded stocks. The sample used in this paper includes both exchange‐traded (NYSE/AMEX) companies and NASDAQ firms. When I split the sample by trading system, I find that the ability of arbitrage risk to explain the magnitude of the drift remains statistically significant and economically similar for both sorts of firms.

sec.title: Replication on independent sample
sec.p: Because of limited access to institutional‐holding data, the sample used in this paper is constrained to begin in the second quarter of 1991. The coefficient on the institutional‐holding variable, however, turns out to be insignificant in all tests. Dropping this variable allows me to replicate the regression tests over the period from the third quarter of 1984, when quarterly earnings forecasts became available on I/B/E/S, through the first quarter of 1991. For this independent sample, the coefficient on arbitrage‐risk variables remains significantly positive at the 1% level. I cannot reject the hypothesis that the effect of arbitrage risk on the drift is the same over both time periods.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Some researchers believe that post‐earnings‐announcement drift is a result of methodological limitations, while others maintain it is caused by researchers who systematically missestimate expected returns following earnings announcements. A third typical explanation is that the drift reflects a slow market reaction to earnings information. The underreaction explanation obviously violates market efficiency.

In part because the drift has survived for several decades, many researchers are quite reasonably reluctant to accept an explanation that is inconsistent with market efficiency. More than one paper asks why investors who are aware of the true time‐series properties of earnings do not arbitrage it away. One possible answer comes from Shleifer and Vishny (1997) and Wurgler and Zhuravskaya (2002), who argue that real‐world arbitrage is risky. This paper presents a test that can discriminate the underreaction hypothesis from the other two. Only the underreaction hypothesis predicts that post‐earnings‐announcement drift will be greater for stocks that are riskier to arbitrage.

Controlling for a wide range of firm‐specific characteristics, I find that the magnitude of post‐earnings‐announcement drift is significantly positively related to the risk faced by an arbitrageur who takes a position in the mispriced stock and tries to hedge the position using various market indexes. The results are economically significant and robust to a range of methodological choices. I also find some evidence that the magnitude of the drift is positively related to transactions costs. In total, these results represent new evidence that post‐earnings‐announcement drift reflects underreaction to earnings information and that arbitrage risk and transactions costs impede arbitrageurs who attempt to profit from it.
